comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: Aureliano Blanquet (none in the picture) de hecho fué el general que arrestó a Francisco I. Madero, por órdenes de Victoriano Huerta, en febrero de 1913. José de la Luz Blanco (the man in the picture) luchó al lado de Madero en la Revolución comandada por éste en mayo de 1911 en el Estado de Chihuahua. es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_de_la_Luz_Blanco Dr. Roberto Duarte Cirujano Plástico dr.robertoduarte@hotmail.com

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: If you localize this picture in the Library of Congress Digital Callections hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3b47639 will see the man named here as Gen. Blanquet (who I identified as Gen. Josè de la Luz Blanco) wearing the sames clothes behind right to Francisco I. Madero. That picture was taken at the mountains south of Juàrez, on may 1911 during the siege of that city, and most likely the same day of this. Call number given to this picture obligued to locate it between pictures of events that surely hapened during the Ten Tragic Days, among days from 9 to 18 February, 1913, and not in the events of may 1911. The true Gen. Blanquet may be found in your own collection www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/ggbain.14595/ an you will see the difference, and learn about him in es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aureliano_Blanquet
